title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.13.20 - 21 | 4-10-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: whoever is under the influence of supreme Kala or eternal time must surrender his most dear life and what to speak of other things such as wealth, honour, children, land and home
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verse 20 of the 13th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining that everyone is subject to the influence of time and must surrender everything at death.

segments.key_quote: actually being ignorant of the fact that death always comes suddenly
segments.summary: The speaker provides examples from Srila Prabhupada's teachings and historical events to illustrate the inevitability of death and the surrender of material possessions.

segments.key_quote: there is no powerful living being within the universe who can overcome the influence of time
segments.summary: The speaker expands on the influence of time, explaining that even demigods (devatas) are subject to its power and must relinquish their positions during the partial dissolution of the universe.

segments.key_quote: even in our daily life so many things come and go in which we have no hand but we have to suffer or tolerate them without remedial measure
segments.summary: The speaker describes the devastation caused by the partial dissolution of the universe, where planets are submerged in water, and connects this to the influence of time (kala) in daily life.

segments.key_quote: the king is reminded of his precarious condition influenced by cruel time
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verse 21, focusing on Vidura's message to Dhritarashtra about his precarious situation due to old age, loss of family, and dependence on others.
The speaker explains how time unfolds our karma, bringing both enjoyment and suffering, and highlights the illusory nature of material happiness.
The speaker recounts the tragedies in Dhritarashtra's life, including the deaths of his father, brother, sons, and other relatives, emphasizing his immense loss.

segments.key_quote: the only protector is the Supreme Lord and nobody else
segments.summary: The speaker discusses Dhritarashtra's dependence on Yudhishthira, whom he and Duryodhana considered an enemy, and emphasizes that only the Supreme Lord can provide true protection.

segments.key_quote: one should therefore seek the protection of the Supreme Lord for the human form of life is meant for seeking this particular type of protection
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by reiterating the importance of seeking the Lord's protection and announces that the lecture will continue with further warnings to Dhritarashtra in the following verses.
